newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Stubborn commander saved Israeli from air crash.
newsitem.headline: Stubborn commander saved Israeli from air crash.

text.p: An Israeli soldier escaped death in the mid-air crash of two army helicopters because a stubborn commander enforcing passenger limits forced him off just before takeoff, his family said on Thursday.

"I wanted to tell the story of what was in fact a miracle," said the soldier's uncle Nissim Danna in a call to Israeli army radio two days after all 73 Lebanon-bound soldiers aboard were killed in Israel's worst military air disaster.

The nephew Raz Albahari, 20, boarded one of the two Sikorsky CH-53 transporters but was forced off along with a friend because of army regulations limiting the number who could fly. The two were told they would go next week.
"At the last second they took him off," Danna said, describing a tug-of-war between two officers over what to do with Albahari. Both officers died in the crash.

"One of the commanders said he had to have him at the post because he is a professional guy, an ordnance expert, and the second commander, the senior commander, simply disagreed. Under no circumstance was he prepared to let him board," Danna said.

Albahari, who has served 11 months in Lebanon and was due to spend up to two weeks on duty in Israel's self-declared Lebanon security zone, left on the helicopter a bag of sweets and milk and other items for a friend at the front.
He called his mother to say he was coming home.
It was close to 7 p.m., about the time of the crash. The mother Malka Albahari, 42, told Reuters her son caught a bus and arrived at his home in northern Israel at 8:30 p.m.
News of the crash was first broadcast on Israeli television at 9 p.m.
"Then he put it together these were his friends. All of them were killed," she said.

Albahari, who received psychological and medical treatment at a hospital, raced from funeral to funeral on Wednesday and Thursday, his mother said. The army spokesman barred him from speaking to reporters.
"I got my son as a gift," she said. "It's the hand of God."
